## Table of contents

## Work

When a force causes a body to move, work is done by the force on the body.

Work is equal to the energy that is transferred (to the body) as a result of the force and is the **product of the magnitude of the force and the distance moved in the direction of the force**.

$$
W=Fx
$$

<Columns left="where, ">

$W$ is the work done, in J;

$F$ is the force, in N; and

$x$ is the distance travelled in the direction of the force, in m

</Columns>

#### Example

The block shown in the diagram is pushed 0.5 m along a surface by a force of 20 N.

The work done will be

$$
\begin{align}
W &=Fx \\
&= 20 \times 0.5 \\
&= 10 \text{ J}
\end{align}
$$

This means that 10 J of energy will be transferred to the block.

### Direction of force

Work is defined as the product of the magnitude of the force and the distance moved in **the direction of the force**.

In the diagram below, the distance moved is at an angle to the force applied.

      fill-opacity="0.5"
    />
  </svg>
</div>

In this case the component of the force that acts in the direction of the movement must be calculated, $F\cos{\theta}$.

This means the equation for work will be

$$
W = Fx \cos{\theta}
$$

Therefore, for the example above:

$$
\begin{align}
W&= 20 \times 0.5 \times cos \times 30 \\
&=8.7 \text{ J}
\end{align}
$$

## Energy

### Potential energy and kinetic energy

A body can have kinetic energy due to its motion and potential energy.

The kinetic energy of a body can be calculated using the following equation:

$$
E_k = \frac{1}{2}mv^2
$$

Where $m$ is the mass of the body in kg, $v$ is the velocity in ms<sup>-1</sup> and $E_k$ is the energy in J.

Gravitational potential energy is the energy possessed by an object by virtue of its position. The change in gravitational potential energy can be calculated using this equation:

$$
\Delta E_p=mg \Delta h
$$

Where $m$ is the mass of the body in kg, $g$ is the acceleration due to gravity at sea level = 9.81 ms<sup>-2</sup>, $\Delta h$ is the change in height in m and $\Delta E_p$ is the change in energy in J.

Elastic potential energy is the energy possessed by an object when it has been deformed due to forces acting on it, such as a compressed spring or a stretched rubber band. It is calculated using this equation:

$$
E_e = \frac{1}{2} kx^2
$$

Where $k$ is the spring constant in Nm<sup>-1</sup>, $x$ is the extension in m and $E_e$ is the energy in J.

### Conservation of energy

The work-energy theorem above assumes there are no dissipative/resistive forces involved &mdash; i.e. that the work done on an object transfers perfectly to kinetic energy.

In most real situations here on earth, there&apos;s always some friction, and usually air-resistance too. These forces transfer some of the energy into wasted forms of energy like heat and sound.

Even if some energy is &apos;lost&apos; from the system of objects we&apos;re looking at, the total energy is always conserved &apos; this is the conservation of energy:

<Callout emoji="✏️">

Energy cannot be created or destroyed, only transferred from one form to another.

</Callout>

If we assume that no friction or air-resistance are acting on the toy car, the gravitational potential energy, $E_p$, would transfer perfectly into kinetic energy, $E_k$. The speed calculated would be the &apos;theoretical maximum&apos;.

$$
\Delta E_p = E_{k \text{ gain}}
$$

However, when we also consider frictional forces, we then write:

$$
\Delta E_p = E_{k \text{ gain}} + W
$$

where $W$ is the work done by the frictional forces ($W=Fx$), the speed **measured** would be significantly less than the 'theoretical maximum' calculated with no frictional forces.

## The work-energy relationship

Work done is a measure of how much energy is transferred.

In the example below, a force is applied which causes a block to move. Therefore, we would say that work is done on the block.

    <rect

      width="65.959"
      height="16.3036"
      fill="currentColor"
      fill-opacity="0.5"
    />
  </svg>
</div>

This means that there is a transfer of energy: if no friction is acting on the block, it will accelerate and the energy transfer causes an increase in the kinetic energy of the block. The increase in kinetic energy is equal to the work done.

This can be written as the following equation:

$$
Fx= \frac{1}{2}mv^2 - \frac{1}{2}mu^2
$$

Where $F$ is the force in N, $x$ is the distance travelled in the direction of the force in m, $m$ is the mass of the body in kg and $u$ and $v$ are the initial and final velocity in ms<sup>-1</sup>.

<Callout emoji="💡">

Remember, if the force acts at an angle to the direction of movement, the component of the force in the direction of movement, $F \cos{\theta}$, must be used.

</Callout>

#### Example

In the diagram below, a sled is shown being pushed along a frozen surface. (Friction is negligible as a result of this.) The mass of the sled is 10 kg.

As a force is applied to the sled, it causes a transfer of energy, work, to be done on the sled. This causes the sled to accelerate, increasing the kinetic energy.

The final velocity can be calculated using the work-energy relationship.

$$
Fx= \frac{1}{2}mv^2 - \frac{1}{2}mu^2
$$

Substituting the values into the equation gives

$$
30 \times 20 = \frac{1}{2} \times 10 \times v^2 - \frac{1}{2} \times 10 \times 4^2
$$

Solving the equation gives a value of $v = 11.7$ ms<sup>-1</sup>.

In this case, it is assumed that the force is constant and is always in the direction of movement, and that there are no resistive or dissipative forces acting on the sled.

### Power

<Callout emoji="⚡️">

Power is defined as the rate of energy transfer. It is the amount of energy that is transferred per second and is measured in W where 1 W = 1 Js<sup>-1</sup>.

</Callout>

It can be calculated using the following equation:

$$
\begin{align}
P = \frac{W}{t} = \frac{\Delta E}{t}
\end{align}
$$

<Columns left="where,">

$P$ is the power, in W;

$W$ is the work done, in J;

$t$ is the time, in s; and

$\Delta E$ is the change in energy, in J

</Columns>

_For example, if it takes \_5s_ to move the block in the diagram below, the power can be calculated using the equation $P = \frac{W}{t}$.\_

$$
\begin{align}
W &= Fx \\
&= 20 \times 0.5 \\
&= 10 \text{ J}
\end{align}
$$

$$
\begin{align}
P &= \frac{W}{t} \\
&= \frac{10}{5} \\
&= 2 \text {W}
\end{align}
$$

### Dissipative forces

Consider the previous example of the sled being pushed across a frozen surface. If the same sled is pushed across a gravel surface, a 30 N force maintains a constant 4 ms<sup>-1</sup> velocity.

    width="650"
    height="107"
    viewBox="0 0 650 107"

      stroke-opacity="0.3"
      stroke-width="2.4"
    />
    <path
      d="M517.011 74.5838L536.849 40.2242L556.686 74.5838H517.011Z"
      stroke="currentColor"
      stroke-opacity="0.3"
      stroke-width="2.4"

    <path
      d="M196.326 84.3633L203.382 80.2895L203.382 88.437L196.326 84.3633Z"
      fill="currentColor"
    />
    <line
      x1="203.382"
      y1="84.4396"
      x2="587.668"
      y2="84.4397"
      stroke="currentColor"
      stroke-width="2.4"
    />
    <path
      d="M594.724 84.3633L587.668 80.2895L587.668 88.437L594.724 84.3633Z"
      fill="currentColor"
    />
  </svg>
</div>

The same amount of work is being done, $W=Fx=30\times 20=600$ J, but does not cause an increase in the kinetic energy of the sled. This is due to friction acting on the sled with an equal but opposite force, thus opposing the motion. The work is being done against friction, causing the energy to be transferred into internal energy.

In most examples of energy transfer, there will be some energy lost as internal energy due to resistive or dissipative forces such as friction or air resistance. However, the principle of conservation of energy will still apply. For example, a sled with 100 J of gravitational potential energy at the top of a slope will gain kinetic energy once it is released. Conservation of energy means that at the bottom of the slope, the sled should have 100 J of kinetic energy.

When the velocity of the sled is measured, the kinetic energy is less than 100 J. This is due to the frictional forces acting on the sled.

The work done by the frictional forces will be equal to the difference in the gravitational potential energy at the start and the kinetic energy at the end.

#### Efficiency

Efficiency is a measure of how much of the energy input is transferred into useful energy. It is calculated using this equation:

$$
\text{\% efficiency} = \frac{\text{useful energy transfer}}{\text{total input energy}} \times 100\text{\%}
$$

For example, an electric winch used to lift a lifeboat out of the water uses 150,000 J of electrical energy. The lifeboat gains 120,000 J of gravitational potential energy. The efficiency of the winch can be calculated using the following equation:

$$
\begin{align}
\text{\% efficiency} &= \frac{120000}{150000} \times 100\text{\%} \\
&= 80\text{\%}
\end{align}
$$
